BACKGROUND AND RECENT DEVELOPMENTS
A. Country Status
1 Afghanistan is one of the poorest and longest-suffering countries among the members of the World Bank. An estimated seven million people remain vulnerable to hunger and very large numbers are dependent on a massive inflow of food aid. Afghanistan's infrastructure has been destroyed or degraded; its human resource base severely depleted; and its social capital eroded. State institutions are largely non- functional, and the economy and society have become increasingly fragmented.
2 The Afghanistan Interim Administration and its successor, the Transitional Islamic State of Afghanistan (TISA) have moved quickly to restore basic government functions and re-establish international relations. However, expectations among the population for a "peace dividend" are high, and if TISA does not deliver results relatively quickly, the prospects for further progress and the peace process will dim.
3 Despite being hampered by very limited capacity and the difficult security situation in many parts of the country, the TISA has made considerable progress and has gained widespread international recognition. A budget has been passed by the TISA Cabinet laying out an ambitious agendaof reconstruction, reform and growth for the next two years.
B. Features of the Existing Communications Sector
4. Afghanistan has a barely functioning, very limited communications sector. Prior to the recent bombing campaign, Afghanistan's telecommunications network operated approximately 57,000 lines in five major cities (two thirds of these lines were in Kabul). These appear to have largely survived the bombing.
5 The Ministry of Communications (MOC) operates a digital service mainly in Kabul, Herat and Mazar where recent national and international satellite links have now been established. Kabul has recently installed a 12,000 fixed line digital switch with 7,000 active lines. Herat includes a 7,500 fixed line digital system, most of which are active and Mazar has a capacity of 4,000 lines, most of which are also active. The MOC also operates an analogue network mainly in Kabul with an estimated 8,000 active lines although the switch does have a capacity of 15,000 lines. Instanet is currently completing the installation of five Very Small Aperture Terminals (VSATs) in the five main cities of Afghanistan on behalf of the MO. These will give the MOC limited backbone transmission to connect its digital lines.
6 Afghan Wireless Communications Company (AWCC), which is a joint venture with the MOC, currently operatesa digital wired service in Kabul connecting some of the Ministries and a score of public telephone booths to its international satellite switch. There are similar operations in Herat and Mazar with lower numbers whilst Kandahar is estimated to have 750 active lines. AWCC has recently launched a Global Standard for Mobile (GSM) service in Kabul with plans to offer service in the five major cities within
1  two months. A new mobile operator is currently testing its services for full release in the near future. The operator was selected through a process of competitive bidding earlier this year.
7 However, country teledensity remains on the order of two telephones per 1,000 people compared to 24 per thousand in Pakistan, 35 in Tajikistan, 68 in Uzbekistan, and 83 in Turkmenistan. The fixed analogue, fixed digital and wireless digital networks present in Kabul are not interconnected.
8. At present, the Government's abilities to coordinate its own operations are severely limited by inadequate communications capacity between Ministries in Kabul - in the majority of cases, inter-Ministry communications requires either physical transfer of information or meetings. This constraint extends to the capacity to communicate with other actors in Kabul and internationally, with very few telephone lines and even less Internet capacity (the majority of Ministries have no effective access to the Internet at all). Most Ministries also have no capacity to communicate with the provinces. Da Afghanistan Bank (DAB) has limited satellite-based connectivity with its provincial Banks, and it is likely that the Ministry of Finance (MOF), at least in the short term, will be able to share that capacity. Given the scale of demand and the limited nature of the DAB network, however, the rest of the Kabul Government has effectively no access to their regional counterparts. Furthermore, the design of the DAB network is unsuitable for more intensive use.
9 Postal services are also recovering from years of conflict. There is a post office in every district, and the potential for the postal network to function as not only a delivery vehicle for letter and parcels, but also government services, other communications technologies and (potentially) financial services. However, at present, many post offices are dilapidated and lack even such basic equipment as scales and franking machines. Even the central post office in Kabul lacks basic mail handling and processing equipment.
C. TISA Objectives
10 The overriding objective of the TISA's national communications policy is to achieve modernization and rapid expansion of telecommunications networks and services, and to aim for universal accessto telecommunications across Afghanistan. The TISA recognizes that in order to achieve this, it is important to create the right conditions for open competition and private sector investment by ensuring a stable and transparent policy, legal and regulatory environment.
11. Policy will also evolve toward a technologically neutral, open and convergent status. Certain distinctions may remain for purposes of licensing and regulation, for example for those services depending upon scarce resources and to support accessgoals. The primary objective, however, is to lessen artificial technology and service barriers, and to encourage the forces of convergence and market innovation to promote widespread accessto a range of affordable communications services.  12 A Telecommunications Act is being finalized and the government is presently working to set up an independent Telecommunications Regulatory Authority of Afghanistan (TRAA). Afghanistan will ensure that the TRAA is completely independent of any operator or service provider in the ICT sector. For the coming months, with support from the Public Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility (PPIAF), an interim Telecommunications Review Board has been established in the MOC to prepare the ground for the establishment of the TRAA by the end of 1382.
13. During the 5-year period covered by the existing policy, the TISA's clear intention is the corporatization of the Ministry's fixed telecommunications operations. The corporatization process (supported under the proposed project) will commence as a priority in the last three months of 2003, with the creation of the new corporation planned for 2004. The Ministry is planning to invite a strategic partner to manage Afghan Tel post-corporatization. Plans for eventual privatization will be augmented by an institutional strengthening exercise to ensure administration procedures and accountability to meet all international quality and performance expectations. Although foreign investors are invited and encouraged to demonstrate their commitment by forming joint ventures with local partners, there is no minimum requirement for local equity partners.
14 The cellular market has two privately run national licensed operators. For long distance and international telephony, the government has invested in some capacity with the assistance of the Afghanistan Reconstruction Trust Fund (ARTF), but all mobile and fixed licensees also have the right to operate long distance and international services independently of the MOC-controlled operator. International (facilities) licenses are also available for Internet usage - subject to separate VSAT licensing, where appropriate (presently only on a temporary basis).
15 A Telecommunications Development Fund (TDF) will be established to help support the rapid development of universal access in areas that may be perceived as uneconomic by the market. This Fund will be administered by the TRAA, and will be separately identified under the Commission's operating budget. Where feasible, funds will be employed to facilitate investment in market-oriented, sustainable operations, which will not require further subsidy following initial start-up funding. Notwithstanding this requirement, the Fund will be utilized to support the most beneficial investments and services in locations most in need of communications infrastructure. Use of the Fund will also be coordinated with other public service projects, such as educational and health facilities.
16 As part of the National Development Budget and as a centerpiece of the draft Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) Policy, the MOC has laid out as a major priority for communications development over the next year the expansion and improved functioning of the government's own communications system. The MOC expects to be the lead agency in rolling out this system as a matter of urgency, in order to improve the ability of the TISA to govern. The TISA recognizes the vital need for improved government communications to allow more efficient governance, greater transparency, and greater interaction with the provinces.
3  17 The TISA is keen to see the rehabilitation of the postal network both to allow the delivery of parcels and letters, but also to expand the use of post offices as a point of interaction between government and citizen and, potentially, a location for voice and data communications access and financial service delivery. The administration has already undertaken some innovative public-private ventures to improve service delivery, including an arrangement whereby a private company provides stamps to the postal system for no charge in return for the right to issue stamps to collectors worldwide.
II. INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION (IDA) ASSISTANCE STRATEGY
A. The Transitional Support Strategy
18 The Transitional Support Strategy (TSS), presented to the Executive Directors of IDA in March 2003, is predicated on the need for well-coordinated efforts by Afghanistan's development partners to realize Afghanistan's emergency reconstruction and development priorities. The key objectives of IDA's assistance are: (i) improving livelihoods; (ii) fiscal strategy, institutions and management; (iii) governance and public administration reform; and (iv) enabling private sector development. This project will in particular support the third and fourth goals. By allowing far more straightforward government communications within Kabul and to the provinces, government administrative capacity will be significantly enhanced. By supporting policy and regulatory development for the sector as a whole, the project will enable expanded provision of private, competitive telecommunications services.
B. Rationale for IDA Involvement in the Communications Sector
19 Modern communications systems are vital to the successful development of Afghanistan. A dependable information system is essential for efficient management and operation of the public and private sectors. This includes areas such as internal government information, citizen's services, trade, banking, and international relations. Across the world, access to telecommunications has been linked to increased incomes, improved delivery of services, the development of enterprises and economic growth.
20 ICT is a sector in which the private sector can take the lead role. Already in Afghanistan, for example, two private operators are leading the way in rolling out access to telecommunications. However, there remain important roles for government oversight and investment. Governments must develop and enforce policies and the regulatory environment required to promote private provision of services. Governments should play a role in extending access beyond that which the market would provide alone, and governments have an important part to play in ensuring that their own operations benefit from access to and use of ICTs to improve governance and government operations. The TISA has recognized these imperatives, and has promulgated policies that support such a role. The TISA has also made specific requests for donor support in the field of communications to help it play that role.
4  21 Donors have begun to respond, including the World Bank. To date, World Bank related support for communications in Afghanistan has been largely provided through trust fund resources. Some support has been given through Analytical and Advisory Services (AAA) to develop draft licensing documents for the MOC, as well as limited support through the First Emergency Public Administration Project for legal assistanceto the Ministry. The larger, trust-funded components, are discussed below:

However, given the limited internal resources of the MOC and the TISA, combined with the urgent need for progress, there remains a significant agenda of support to be met by IDA and other donors.
C. Lessons Learned
28 Experience from post-conflict environments suggests the great importance of wireless communications as the primary telecommunications infrastructure, and the rapidity with which competitive private wireless provision can roll out (even in poor and war-tom environments) under the correct regulatory and policy conditions. This suggests the urgency of creating regulatory and legal institutions that can foster telecommunications rollout, particularly in the wireless segment.
29 The limited (one year) experience of projects in post-conflict Afghanistan as well as `longer experience in other post-conflict environments suggests the importance of intensive project supervision to project success, as well as flexible implementation of project components in a rapidly changing environment. The experience of one year suggests that capacity in line ministries to implement projects remains somewhat limited (although the Ministry of Communications is relatively strong in this regard), and support for training and project management capacity has been included in this project to help ameliorate this situation.  III. THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A. Objective 30 The objective of the proposed Emergency Communications Development Project is to support activities designed to improve delivery of communications services to the Government and to the people of Afghanistan. This will be achieved by: (i) carrying out urgent expansion of the government communications network to restore critical communications between ministries and provinces; (ii) providing urgently needed policy advice and capacity building to the MOC to promote sustainable communications sector performance and increased private sector participation; and (iii) improving the delivery of postal services. The outcomes of the Project are expected to be improvements in communications facilities and delivery, while laying the foundations for sector reforms and institution building which would lead to sustainable development of the communications sector. Monitoring indicators are given in Appendix IV.
B. Project Description
31 The credit has three components, covering: (a) Expanding and integrating the existing Emergency Government Communications Network, (b) MOC Institutional Capacity Building, and (c) Postal Sector Reform. Details of the project components are provided in Appendix 1 and summarized below:
Component 1: Emergency Government Communications Network (US$M million):
32 The component supports: (a) the supply, installation, and commissioning of a communications network that will integrate an existing network constructed by the World Bank and the UNDP, as well as improve and extend coverage to Ministries and other key Government organizations in Kabul as well as Provincial Capitals and selected other sites, and (b) Operations and maintenance and training of Afghan Tel staff. The turnkey service component will support the rollout of a network for government communications utilizing tried and tested technologies in a robust configuration that can be rapidly rolled out in the current Afghan environment.
33 The MOC of TISA presently provides telecommunications services to the following ministries and entities:
l Ministry of Communications l Ministry of Reconstruction l Ministry of Finance l The Central Bank l The Office of the President l The Ministry of Higher Education* l Ministry of Foreign Affairs*
* NB Ministries of Foreign Affairs and Higher Education - microwave link installed and ready for use.

34 In phase one of the Government Communications Network component, the MOC will expand the existing Government Communications Network (GCN) to include an additional 12 ministries which are located in Kabul. These ministries will be connected by fiber or microwave or other suitable communication technology to a central location and connect to a VSAT which will serve as the satellite gateway earth station of the network. In addition to the expansion of the GCN to the 12 ministries, there will also be a requirement to expand the network to 14 priority provincial capitals. In phase two of the project, the remaining ministries, provincial capitals and selected other sites will be connected.
35 The operation and maintenance (O&M) contract will run for the remaining life of the project or until such time that both the MOC and the World Bank are satisfied that capacity exists within the corporatized Afghan Tel to transfer operating responsibility and ownership to Afghan Tel. This project component will also pay for sufficient training of Afghan Tel staff to provide them with the capacity to operate the Government Communications network. From that point onwards, the communications network operator will be under standard regulatory oversight and act as part of a commercial (government owned) corporation. It is expected that, in the medium term (three years), this company will be privatized, and operate as a standard telecommunications services provider.
36 The component will also cover training. MOC staff lack sufficient opportunities to *develop the skills necessary to operate and maintain the various equipment to be deployed in the GCN. Therefore a significant component of this project is the provision of formal training for a team of MOC staff in order that they can develop the ability to maintain the GCN independently and efficiently.
37 It will be required that the bidder selected to expand the network, and provide O&M services, also provide these training services. Penalties will be built into the contract for failure to deliver training within the agreed timeframe without justifiable reasons.

C. Sustainability
41. Given the security situation and the fragile status of the economy and TISA, sustainability is of serious concern. Within the limited area of sustainability issues amenable to amelioration through project design, however, a number of steps will be taken to enhance sustainability.
0 The government communications network is designed to be financially self sustaining over the medium term through internal charging for services (the MOC will charge other Ministries and government users for their use of the network). The intention to privatize the telecommunication provider should enhance the likelihood of this sustainability.
0 Technical sustainability will be enhanced through training and the ability to pay technicians competitive salaries through corporatization and
11  private sector involvement. Further, during the life of the project (four years), the service contractor will stay in place as operator and maintainer of the network until such time that the Bank and the MOC are comfortable that the network can be sustained by Afghan Tel.
a Support for policy and regulatory reform is expected to have a sustained impact. Given that a number of private operators are already active in the telecommunications field, it appears that there is considerable likelihood that private, competitive service provision will prove a success in Afghanistan as it has worldwide, generating revenues through license fees and payments significant enough to sustain the required regulatory capacity to overseethat provision.
42 Support for postal reform and investment will have a sustainable impact if the postal sector develops a sound sector policy and development strategy along with improved capacity to operate efficiently and generate revenues. Improved basic equipment, corporatization, an understanding of existing and future postal market demand, and support for improved management are first steps in achieving improved network performance and revenue generation. Given the relatively small investments in this sub-sector envisaged in the project, and the imrnediate need for a basic communications infrastructure, the impact of these investments should also be sustainable through delivering and collecting chargesfor improved service.
43 The project is potentially at risk from the general security position in Afghanistan. This particularly relates to the government communications network component, which will involve activities in all 32 provinces. Security issues will be taken into account during the design and operation of the project. However, like most of the current reconstruction and development efforts, the long term sustainability of the project is likely to be tied to the general security situation in the country.
IV. INSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION
A. Institutional Arrangements
44 The project would be implemented over a period of three and a half years. Project completion date would be March 20, 2007, and the Credit closing date would be September 30, 2007. This comparatively long time period for an emergency project is to help ensure sustainability. In particular, the government communications network component is urgently required to improve governance capacity, however, the MOC lacks the technical and financial resources required to operate the network at the current time. This emergency project will allow for rapid rollout of the network, while an extended project lifetime will ensure network operation can be supported under the project until such time that there is the local capacity to operate the network in a self- sustaining manner.
45 The Executing agency for the project would be the Ministry of Communications, with assistance to be provided on matters involving financial management and
12  procurement by the Afghanistan Assistance Coordination Authority Procurement Consultant. The MOC will be responsible for procurement of goods, works and services estimated to cost up to US$25,000 per contract, following the provisions of the Credit Agreement. Beyond this limit, procurement will be carried out with the assistanceof the Procurement Consultant at the AACA, with technical inputs from the MOC.
B. Procurement
46 The IDA Emergency Public Administration Project is funding the services of a Procurement Consultant to support the AACA and various ministries. The Procurement Consultant will be responsible for assisting with the procurement of all goods and consultancy services for the Emergency Communications Project. Procurement capacity in MOC is being strengthened with suitable training. To ensure that procurement capacity is built up, Procurement Consultant will provide training to MOC staff, as well as other staff as deemed necessary to ensure that they develop capacity to eventually carryout procurement on their own. MOC will appoint a Project Management Specialist to oversee the implementation of the proposed project. Until funds under the project become available Emergency Infrastructure Reconstruction Project funds will fund the specialist. MOC will also provide an implementation plan outlining unit and personnel responsibilities for selection and management of consultants as well as procurement and operation of goods.
47. Goods and consulting services financed under the Project shall be procured in accordance with the Bank's Procurement Guidelines and Guidelines for Selection and Employment of Consultants, and using the Bank's standard bidding documents. Each contract for goods estimated to be equivalent of US$300,000 or more and the first three contracts for goods procured under international or national shopping, shall be subject to prior review by IDA. Each contract for employment of consulting firms estimated to cost more than US$lOO,OOOand more than US$50,000 in case of individual consultants, shall be subject to prior review by IDA. All other contracts will be subject to the post award review. Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) would be the preferred method for most of the consultancies. However, selection based on Consultants' Qualifications (CQ) and Individual Consultants (IC) may be adopted for other consultancy services. Detailed procurement arrangements are provided in Appendix III.
C. Disbursement And Financial Management
48 Since there is no Country Profile of Financial Accountability (CPFA) or Country Financial Accountability Assessment (CFAA) for Afghanistan, there is inadequate knowledge of country issues and related strengths and weaknesses. Financial management capacity in the country is not fully functional and appropriate mitigation measures have been implemented through the engagement of the Financial Management Agent. The Financial Management Agent will be responsible for assisting the MOF to maintain the accounts for all Government expenditures, including the proposed MOC project, in addition to building capacity within TISA. Standard quarterly progress reports
13  will be prepared. The Project Management Specialist (PMS) in the MOC will support the financial and implementation arrangements of this project. There may need to be additional capacity in the Financial Management Agent (FMA) to accommodate this project due to the increasing number of projects.
49 Funds Flow: Funds flow under the project will use the existing government system as much as possible. As is the practice for government expenditure, all project payments will be routed through the Ministry of Finance (MOF). The Financial Management Agent will support the MOF in executing and recording project payments.

D. Environment And Social Safeguard
55 The reconstruction and investment interventions envisaged under the proposed project are not expected to generate significant negative environmental effects. No activities will be supported that require involuntary land acquisition or the acquisition of land. Consequently, no Resettlement Action Plan will be required for the proposed project.
14  56. Network and spectrum monitoring equipment will be housed in existing buildings and will not involve building construction. The government communications service operator is expected to use VSAT and other wireless technologies to deploy services. As a result of this choice of technology, there is no need to build accessroads, new buildings or large power-supply installations. Moreover, the installation of compact, modular VSAT equipment will not adversely affect the aesthetics of rural areas. It should be noted, however, that it is possible under an alternative configuration that in Kabul the service provider may utilize spurs off an existing fiber optic system to provide connectivity to some ministries. If that does occur, minimal ducting may be required. The service contract will specify that such ducting will traverse only public rights of way and involve no major construction work.
57 Gender: The last twenty years of social upheaval has greatly affected the overall gender situation in Afghanistan, resulting in very restrictive policies vis-a-vis women's participation in public life, accessto education and other services as well as employment opportunities. During the Taliban regime, women and girls were effectively excluded from any participation in public life. With the replacement of the Taliban regime, women have regained the right to education, employment opportunities and services, but the prevailing social norms are still very conservative and restrictive regarding women's participation in the national development effort. There are huge differences between Kabul and the much smaller secondary cities, and the rural areas. In addition, there are considerable regional differences with the south and southeastern areas of the country being more restrictive and conservative than the western and northern areas. These variations to some extent coincide with ethnic differences. To this should be added the great difference in outlook of returning refugees (whether repatriating from the West or from the neighboring countries) and those who remained in Afghanistan.
58. ICT is a major sector in which gender imbalances can be addressed, through increased employment opportunities for women. In addition, by allowing for the increased flow of information to and from Kabul and the provinces, as well as allowing for the more efficient operation of government in general, the project will act to strengthen the ability of the Authority to carry out its polices designed to decreasethe inequality of opportunity between women and men.

9 Disbursement Method: Disbursements from the IDA credit would be transaction- based (replenishment, reimbursement, direct payment and payments under Special Commitments) with full documentation or against statements of expenditures as appropriate.
10 Use of statements of expenditures (SOEs): Disbursements will be made on the basis of SOEs for: (a) consultants and training for contracts not exceeding US$lOO,OOO for firms and US$SO,OOOfor individuals; and (b) goods for contracts not exceeding us$300,000.
11 Special Account: A Special Account would be opened and maintained in a bank acceptable to the Association; and would be operated by MOF in accordance with the Association's operational policies. The Authorized Allocation of the Special Account would be US$l.3 million which represents the estimated amount of expenditures to course through the Special Account in a 3-month period. Given the short disbursement period and the immediate need for special account funds, the full amount of the Authorized Allocation of the Special Account will be available to MOF upon effectiveness.
12 Minimum application size. Applications for replenishment to the Special Account will be submitted (a) monthly, or (b) when the Special Account balance is reduced by 40 percent, whichever comes first. The minimum application size for withdrawal applications for reimbursement, direct payment, or for applications for Special Commitments is 20 percent of the Authorized Allocation of the Special Account. In the event that banking facilities are not fully functional at Grant effectiveness, IDA may, on an exceptional basis, waive minimum application size requirements in order to accommodate urgent needs.
13. Authority to withdraw Grant funds: MOF will retain the right to sign and submit withdrawal applications to the Association.
Supervision Plan
14. From a financial management perspective, the Project will need intensive supervision. The focus during the supervision will be on the internal control arrangements for the Project and functioning of accounting, financial reporting and auditing.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Emergency Communications Development Project is to support activities designed to improve delivery of communications services to the government, and to the people of Afghanistan. This will be achieved by: 1) carrying out urgent expansion of the government communications network, to restore critical communications between ministries, and provinces; 2) providing urgently needed policy advice, and capacity building to the Ministry of Communications (MOC) to promote sustainable communications sector performance, and increased private sector participation; and, 3) improving the postal sector, and the delivery of postal services. The outcomes of the Project are expected to be improvements in communications facilities, and delivery, while laying the foundations for sector reforms, and institution building, which would lead to sustainable development of the communications sector. While benefits include improved government communications capacity, sector development, and reform, leading to greater communications access, and increased private investment, there are however risks, such as the technical and financial sustainability of government network (mitigated through design), but as well, general security, and institutional weaknesses.
